intro: Sisymbrium foliosum, commonly known as the leafy whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, pinnately lobed leaves. Its small, yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom in late spring to early summer. Sisymbrium foliosum is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and waste areas.
